I don't know a huge amount about getting a job as a generalist but your friend is right to a certain extent. I wouldn't expect a big place like Framestore or DNeg to be on the lookout for generalist very often (although I believe those positions are available). Generalist positions you would either usually find a (much) smaller studios (I'm thinking 15 or less people) as they need a small amount of people to do a lot of work. Additionally, being a generalist can be quite good for freelancing as, sadly, clients often don't understand how much work goes into making something. Of course you know "I need an animation made" probably means they want the model, rig, animation, renders, everything done. Which isn't great for someone like me who is only really good at animating, but as a generalist you could quite easily do yourself or potentially with a friend or two.

If you're looking to get into the bigger studios I would probably recommend focusing on one area and then also keep up with the adjacent disciplines. For example, if you concentrated on animation then rigging would be a good one to also focus on. With modelling then you would also focus on texturing, lighting etc. Being multi-disciplined would be a big help as it makes you more desirable as an employee because you can help out in areas other than your own.
There's no reason you can't do the other stuff as individual/personal projects at home.

I had a very quick look on the Framestore site and they have Generalist in specific positions. So one opening they have now is a Houdini Generalist. So even though you're a generalist you still work mostly in Houdini. So not crazy general like you might expect to find at a smaller studio where you may be responsible for creating the whole character and then passing it over to an animator or coder or something.

Does that all make sense? If you have any other questions or I haven't been clear enough (I tend to waffle a lot) then please let me know. I'm here and happy to help =]
